title: EU consumer group wants to ban carbon-neutral claims - Food Business News
summary: Carbon-neutral claims on products are misleading and scientifically inaccurate, according to the European consumer organization BEUC. The BEUC is asking the European Union to ban the use of carbon-neutral claims for all products, including food and drink products. The Climate Neutral Group includes carbon offsetting as a way to help companies achieve carbon neutrality, but says that offsetting should not be a free pass to continue emitting greenhouse gasses.

green_process: TRUE. The referenced innovation of carbon offsetting and carbon credits is a green process that helps companies reduce their carbon footprint by investing in projects that reduce or remove greenhouse gasses from the atmosphere.

title: EU urged to ban 'carbon neutral' claims for food and drink: 'There's no such thing as a CO2 neutral banana' - FoodNavigator.com
summary: The European Consumer Organisation (BEUC) is calling for a ban on all carbon neutral claims, including ‘carbon neutral’, ‘CO2 neutral’, ‘carbon positive’, and ‘carbon neutral certified’, arguing that they are misleading and scientifically inaccurate. BEUC believes such claims mislead consumers, giving the false impression that the products are a good choice for the planet. The Carbon Trust, which measures and certifies companies’ carbon neutral claims, agrees that claims such as ‘carbon positive’ or ‘climate negative’ should be off the table.

summary: Haeckels, a Margate-based skincare company, has launched three new products as part of its Haeckels Lab range, which explores lab-grown ingredients to reduce emissions and promote sustainability. The new products include a cleansing milk, toner, and serum, which are made with a proprietary ingredient called Spiraglow that has been shown to reduce fine lines and wrinkles by up to 22%. Haeckels plans to launch additional products in the future through a "test then drop" method, which will allow them to test products without the need for long production runs and bespoke packaging.

title: Cauldron set to supercharge precision fermentation - Food & Drink Business
summary: Cauldron, an Australian start-up, has raised $10.5 million to build Asia-Pacific’s largest network of precision fermentation facilities. Precision fermentation is a form of synthetic biology that uses genetically engineered microorganisms to custom-make a wide range of molecules, including proteins, fats, and fibres. Cauldron's technology will enable companies to produce new food, feed, and fibre products more efficiently and at a lower cost than conventional methods.

green_process: TRUE. Precision fermentation is a green process because it has the potential to reduce the environmental impact of manufacturing by reducing the need for energy-intensive processes and the use of hazardous chemicals.
